stem: A 66-year-old client who is 3 days post-hip replacement suddenly screams, 'I can't breathe!' and clutches his chest. Based on the documentation in the VTE Risk & Coagulation Protocol tab, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, the two actions the nurse should take, and the two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: Acute respiratory distress in a post-surgical client.
Background: Right hip arthroplasty. BMI 34. History of tobacco use. Currently on bed rest.
Assessment: Chest pain is worsening with inspiration (Pleuritic). Skin is dusky and pale.
Recommendation: Immediate V/Q scan or CT Angiography.

tabs.title: VTE Risk & Coagulation Status
tabs.content:
Assessment ItemFindingRisk Level
MobilityBed rest (Day 3)High Risk
ProphylaxisSequential Compression Devices (SCDs)In patient room (Off during shower)
D-Dimer1,450 ng/mL (High)Significant clot breakdown
PTT (Baseline)28 secondsNormal

tabs.title: Vital Signs
tabs.content: BP 132/86, HR 118, RR 32, SpO2 84% on RA. Client is gasping for air.

actionOptions.text: Elevate the head of the bed (HOB) to 45–90 degrees
Initiate an IV Heparin infusion as prescribed
Encourage the client to ambulate to improve circulation
Apply heat packs to the right calf for comfort

parameterOptions.text: Continuous pulse oximetry and respiratory rate
Activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) (Monitor for heparin)
Presence of a positive Babinski sign

rationale.correct: This is a classic Pulmonary Embolism (c2) triggered by post-surgical immobility. Key findings: Pleuritic pain, acute hypoxia (SpO2 84%), tachycardia, and a high D-Dimer. Priority actions: Optimizing gas exchange via HOB elevation (a1) and stopping clot propagation with Heparin (a2). Key parameters: Oxygenation/RR (p1) to track stability and aPTT (p2) to manage the therapeutic range of Heparin.
clinicalPearls: In a PE emergency, the priority is 'Up with the HOB, On with the O2.'
Heparin does NOT dissolve the clot; it prevents it from getting bigger while the body’s own plasmin system dissolves it.
The gold standard for diagnosis is a Computed Tomography Pulmonary Angiography (CTPA).

questionTrap.trap: Asking the patient with a suspected PE to walk for circulation.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Walk for PREVENTION. Stay in bed for the ACTUAL clot. If they have a PE, moving around could dislodge more emboli or worsen the cardiac strain.

mnemonic.title: PE Cues
mnemonic.expansion: P-Pleuritic pain. E-Emergency HOB. E-Elevated D-Dimer.
